title: Asia shares, U.S. futures rise as Greece, China fears cool
text:
Asian Stocks Rise With U.S. Futures on Greece, China; Yen Slides By Emma O'Brien 22 minutes ago  Content preferences Done 
Asian stocks rose with U.S. index futures, while the yen weakened on easing concern that China’s equity rout and Greece’s debt crisis will infect the global economy. The euro gained while Treasuries retreated. 
The MSCI Asia Pacific Index added 1.2 percent by 10:46 a.m. in Tokyo, trimming the gauge’s weekly drop to 3.1 percent, the most since March 2014. Chinese stocks rallied and Standard & Poor’s 500 Index futures gained 1 percent. The euro strengthened 0.5 percent to $1.1086, and gained 0.8 percent versus the yen. Ten-year Treasury yields advanced three basis points, with Australian and Japanese bonds falling a second day. U.S. crude oil held onto gains. 
More from Bloomberg.com: NYSE Halt Roils Market as Malfunction Hits Biggest Exchange 
The Shanghai Composite Index is heading for its first back-to-back gain since June 24 after the government banned insiders from selling stocks, and as almost half of listed companies remain halted. Greece submitted a reform package, the details of which emerged after U.S. markets closed, that contains proposals similar to those demanded by creditors. The request will be discussed at a European Union summit on Sunday. 
“‘‘The fact that China managed to close up across the board has certainly reduced market fear, but it’s still very much in the forefront of people’s minds,” Sam Tuck, a senior currency strategist in Auckland at ANZ Bank New Zealand Ltd., said by instant message. “Signs that the proposal Greece has put together has concessions on long-standing issues and is similar to tabled proposals is reducing risk aversion.” 
More from Bloomberg.com: Greeks Under Gun to Produce a Reform Plan to Keep Euro 
Greece’s proposed reforms were similar to those presented by the European Commission on June 26. They sales-tax increases and cuts in public spending on pensions. Greece also proposed the restructuring of its debt and a package of growth measures of 35 billion euros. The proposal will be put before the Greek Parliament Friday. 
The Shanghai Composite rose 4.4 percent in early trade, while Hong Kong’s Hang Seng China Enterprises Index advanced 3.1 percent. 
Japan’s Topix index climbed 1.1 percent after a two-day loss of more than 3 percent. The Nikkei 225 Stock Average added 0.4 percent. The yen, which typically moves at odds with Japanese equities, dropped to 121.91 per dollar, cutting its gain in the week to 0.9 percent.
